title: How and where to sell old coins? - Quora

response.answer_text: You have a lot of options. The one you decide on will depend on how quickly you want to sell them, the quality of the coins, the type of coins and the way you sell them. First, the description “old coins” is not very helpful in giving you advice on selling your specific coins. My coins are mostly between 1,000 and 2,750 years old. Most Numismatists and collectors consider any coins minted more recently than 1600 CE to be modern. There are many ways to sell the coins. If you want to do it yourself you can go to eBay, Collectivecoin.com, tantaluscoins.com, amazon and many other websites that let you list things for sales. Some of these sites are specifically aimed at coin collectors, some are flee markets. As with all the ways to sell your coins, this way has many advantages and disadvantages. On the plus side, the fees you will pay are less than the other options and you can set your own prices. The disadvantages are larger: Less traffic on the website, lower average sales prices, you have to do all the work yourself and you need to know the correct prices to place on the coins. Another way to sell your coins is to consign the coins to an auction house. Auctions generally charge the consignor 10–15% of the sales price but some places also have minimum fees per coin. The average fees also vary by the type of coin. The major problems with this sales arrangement is that you may wait a long time before the coin is listed in an auction, final sales prices are frequently well below retail value of the coins (although some coins inexplicably sell for many times what they are estimated at) and payment is made only after the buyer pays for the coins. Some auction house will wait for 45, even 90, days after receiving payment to pay the consignor. Coins can also be consigned to a dealer. If a dealer is willing to take your coins on consignment, the fees you pay will average about 20% of the sale price. However you will have to wait for payment until the coin sells and the dealer is, justifiably, going to put more effort into selling the coins that he owns first. These coins will result in more profit for him. Alternatively you can sell the coins directly to a dealer. This may be the most expensive way to get rid of your coins. Dealers will rarely pay more than 30% of what they think they can sell the coin for. This is not because they are ripping you off and is actually a fair price under the circumstances. If a dealer buys your coins, he is doing you a favor. He is taking the coins off your hands and giving you money. He is gambling that he can resell the coins at a profit. He will probably have to hold on to many of them for a long time. He may have to slab some of them at his expense depending on the type and grade of the coin. He needs the sale of the coins he buys to cover his rent and other overhead in addition to the amount he paid you. One other problem with consigning or selling coins to a dealer is finding one. There aren’t a lot of coins stores on main street or in the malls anymore. You may have to look online or, if your not near a major city, travel to a coin show. Also the best payments will come from honest dealers who are knowledgeable about the types of coins you’re selling. Since you don’t already know the dealers, it can be tough to find the right one. (Note: most established dealers are honest. Don't be fooled by the fact that you heat a lot more about the bad ones than the good ones).

First, you need to understand that billions of coins were produced. Many type of metals were used - zinc, copper, bronze, silver, gold and mixture of metals. If you have U.S. coins, they are more valuable to the American collectors. Foreign coins are not valued as highly in the U.S. identify what coin you have - country of origin, denomination, and most importantly the date it was minted. More importantly, find out how many pieces were minted. In U.S. , an old coin from Denver mint, with a “D” marking is more common than “S” , San Francisco mint. The “S” always bring more money.then grade the coin - they range from junk to mint, in the U.S., the highest grading is MS-70 , proof coin. It takes a lot of experience to grade accurately, so unless the coin is worth thousands, you probably don’t want to spend $100 getting it certified. So a local dealer is your friend in this case. The same coin graded average vs mint can mean hundreds of dollars in differencenow, you can get on eBay to see how much people are asking for it, then look at Completed Sales to see how much they ACTUALLY sold for.now you can either list it on eBay, Craigslist, OfferUp, etc. or you can sell it to a coin dealer for about 20% of retail value.Remember that just because a coin is “rare” , it doesn’t mean that people pay big money for it. Collectors change directions all the time, and timing matters. so, what coin do you have??

It is a very reasonable question, because the answer is not as simple as one first thinks. - Trust is the big issue. There are (unfortunately) a lot of fake coins, fake buyers and indeed fake sellers online. So YOU need to be sure whoever you are dealing with is legitimate and likewise they will want to know you are too. If they don’t ask lots of questions of you, my advice is don’t deal with them. Your coins. You need good quality pictures and be prepared to re-photograph with a specified background so the potential buyer sees you have the coin/s not that you have used someone else's image downloaded. You will ideally have a valuation certificate or some history provided for the buyer, this shows you have done your research and therefore know a bit of what you are talking about. You need to describe them honestly and accurately. IF you manage to secure an online deal then be prepared to jump through a few hoops for the buyer, because as I say it is often used as a bit of a test to reassure the buyer. Please ensure you use recorded delivery and adequate insurance. The platform you choose for sale is up to you, EBay is the obvious, there are many on there, but also a lot of fakes. Try online auction houses, but you may have to send them the coins for valuation/verification before they will sell for you, so again choose wisely. I am not sure where you re based, but to be honest with you the best way to sell them is through a local auction house to yourself, one that is linked to an online system, as they get buyers from all over the world and will value them as part of the sale process, I for one prefer to use this method to buy as I know the auction house will not knowingly sell fakes, plus if they do I have comeback on them. I hope this helps, if I can be of further assistance please contact me HOME Nigel. Director Bats Publications Ltd. Batcaveenterprises.com

First thing, you need to learn quite a bit about your coins. Without this knowledge, you’ll either get scammed out of some valuable coins, or try to sell common coins for high prices and get laughed at. So, get the following items: a magnifiyng glass, a pair of white cotton gloves, a pen and a writing pad. Always handle the coins with the gloves on! This because our sweat is quite aggressive to the coins, and collectors want their coins in the best possible condition. With the magnifier, read and note the country, year and face value of the coin. With this data, lookup your coins online. Here Coin catalog, world coins gallery, coin collecting, catalog of world coins - uCoin.net and here Numista are two very good sites to learn more about your coins and to lookup their value. Also read a lot about condition and grading. These are very important. After you know a bit about your coins, you can try selling them. I would suggest finding either a local coin shop or a local coin collector’s (numismatists) forum. These will be the most trustworthy options. Beyond that, and if the coins are in a precious metal (silver, gold, platinum, etc.) those “We buy gold” shops will buy your coins (but will pay you the lowest price they can…) and pawn shops are also an option. Final option is putting them on ebay or some other internet marketplace. Only do this if you really know how to do business online. Thanks for the A2A and good luck Unique :)

You really need to make sure of what they are worth. Old coins don't necessarily have much value unless they are in super condition or rather rare…double struck or very few made or things like that. Go to flea markets or look on E-bay or wherever to get an idea before wasting the time of a coin buyer & seller. You can ask him but after a few looks at your old coins, he may decline to look at any more. Look up coin selling services on the internet…can't think of any off the top of my head…I'll look before I post this response. See what they are asking for their coins, but realize this is strictly retail and you'll be lucky to get wholesale if they were to grade and buy your coins…going locally would be more logical. Perhaps a flea market on consignment - quite often 15% of the sale price, I do believe. Other than that, the bank will give you face value. Okay…just remembered one site and I am not endorsing them nor knocking them…just now I don't have to look it up (lazy me): Littleton Coin Company out of Boulder, Colorado, I believe. That should give you a start…good luck.

It kind of depends on exactly what you mean by old. Collectors of ancient coins (such as myself) and collectors of modern coins kind of work in different worlds. Either way, though, if you ask because you have come across some collectable coins (through an inheritance or something), I really suggest you find yourself a coin dealer and ask for an estimate, then consign them to someone who seems good. I can’t really speak for modern coins, but if a non-collecter were to try to sell an ancient coin on eBay or something then I’d be very suspicious. There are a lot of forgeries out there and we tend to be pretty wary. There are, though, a number of excellent numismatists who have web stores who would probably at least give you a vague idea of what you have if you were to send some photos to them and say you’re interested in a consignment. Some of the biggest include CNG-Ancient Greek, Roman & British Coins and Harlan J Berk. If you’re really talking about ancient coins, then I really like Marc Breitspecher. Tell him I sent you!

eBay’s always available but you have to have a Paypal account or equivalent to sell there. If you get in a dispute with a buyer, Paypal rules for them 90% of the time. You get stiffed on the payment and lose the coin. I’d stick with the traditional way. If you have a long time reputable coin dealer where you live, take the group down to him for an offer or take it to the next local coin show. There are also lots of ways to get valuation info online so you can get an indication of their worth. Here are a few general wholesale price ranges for US coins: common pre 1965 90% silver coins - 7 to 8 times face, 40% Kennedy halves - 3 to 4 times face, common date silver dollars in circulated condition - about $10 each.

I found EBay to be a good place that I sold 2 gold Olympic coins that my grandmother left to me for $1200 earlier this year. I took them to a coin dealer, but he wanted to break them out of their cases, scratch the surface, and then melt them down, and if all that checked out with them being 1 full Troy ounce of 22 karat gold, then he'd give me a thousand dollars. He didn't even look at or care about the certificate of authenticity or the serial number. In addition, he was rude, and acted like he was doing me a favor, so I opted to sell them on EBay to somebody who appreciated them and was willing to pay a fair price. That way ended up being the win/win situation that I was looking for.

If you have not already done so go to a book store and buy a current coin catalogue. This will give you some idea of what your coins may be worth. If you have some valuable coins you may want to have an appraisal done. This will cost you but not a huge amount. Coin dealers will want to buy all your coins in a job lot. This is one time when the sum of the parts will be greater than the whole. If you want to take the time and have the ability and knowledge you can sell the coins yourself. Some Auction houses may be interested in your collection, again depending on what you have. As a stamp collector I firmly believe my collection is the best in the world. Reality usually brings a wake-up and you may be surprised at the value of your collection in the eyes of a dealer. Any collection is only worth what you can persuade some one to pay for it.

It depends on what specific old coins you are looking to sell. If the coins are rare collectibles you will need to find a coin collector that specializes in valuing collectibles. If, on the other hand, your coins are popular precious metal coinage such as gold eagles, silver eagles or junk silver, their value is derived from their precious metal content and they are fairly liquid. Some banks and even western union may accept gold and silver eagles. They are treated the same as foreign currency worldwide. However they may not give you the best exchange rate. Typically the best exchange rates are from online precious metal exchanges that don't require physical store overhead. TradePlacer.com is one such online exchange, but there are many.

There is variety in your options. Depending on the type of coins in your collection, and your feelings about the collection’s value, you could list it on a site like eBay, or take it to an antique dealer specializing in coins. You could take it to a reputable auction house, first getting their opinion of its chances for auction before listing with them. Christie’s or Sotheby's are tops. Powell's is another. You could consult trade magazines (Coin World or Antique Trading, e.g.) for listing in their ads. Your patience and persistence with the process, the types of coins and their condition, and your communication skills will all factor into the results you get. Oh, and take good photos!

Thank you for requesting me to answer your query. There are several ways to sell your collection of old coins. You can put them up for sale on eBay or Amazon. Also, you can contact local coin dealers who purchase and sell coins. They will buy it from you. Another option is to put them up for sale through coin auction houses. If you have old Indian coins to sell then you can contact me as I deal in Indian coins and paper money.

So if anyone interested in your old conies thay will contect you. Also you can use our social media by posting your coins photos and more details. If you have some old cons and you have to sold that please share with me. Thanks.

Ebay, Amazon, anywhere where you can post them. Just watch out that you don't sell it on one platform.For old coins I would really go for Ebay, since most of the ancient artifacts that really mean something are sold there, also you can always promote your sale item through all social media. If they are really old and worth a lot, I would even do facebook and google ads leading to the ebay page.

This is good question where old silver coin are to be sold. First you have to see whether you coins are original silver coins which were in use before independence. These original coins are now have antique value and are not available for sale. If sale these coins, it should fetch higher price from a good jeweller. But It is extremely difficult for a common man to identify that coins are old and antique and original. Now duplicate silver coins or intimate design of old silver coins are available in the market. If you have the same you may sale them with a any good reputed jeweller nearby.

I tired to sell mine on eBay. It wasn't good because coins were underpriced. I tried to sell on Craigslist. No one buys old coins on Craigslist.So I approached to local coin shops and also went to coin exhibits and got what I wanted: nice people with good prices we both agree upon.

Go to a local coin shop or a pawn shop - or several of them. First, get to know the actual value of what you have, and how much different shops/people are willing to pay for them. Definitely educate YOURSELF on this stuff, first. Do some research online - there are several very good coin sites out there. Then, when you know a bit more about what you are doing, go and haggle with the shop owners - or try to sell them online.

you can sell your coins on OLX and Quikr. Numismatic societies will be there depending upon the area, you can sell the coins there. Before Selling the Coins, get a estimate of how much your coin will value.

I am a coin collector since last 10 years. After selling and buying coins for a long period.  I prefer Auctions Houses are the best place for selling coins. That too in its correct market price or above.   In India there are many well known Auction Houses such as:   Todywalla Auction   Bombay Auction   Oswal Auction   Marudhar Auction  Virasat Auction   Try this Auctions for selling your coins.   You will get the best price in market if your is having some Numismatic value.  Hope you will satisfied now.

First. Research what you have. DenominationDateMint Mark Once you know what you have you can either visit a local coin shop and discuss it with them, or, you can contact a Coin Auction House and discuss with them, or, you can open an account on eBay and sell them your self.Opening an account on one of the Coin Chat Boards is always helpful.

Without knowing what coins you have, age, condition, gold silver or any other information I can only suggest that you try eBay or a similar site. It might be best to look at eBay first to get some idea of the value of the coins that you want to sell by finding the same coins that you have and seeing what they sell for, then if you have anything valuable you can set a reserve on it.

I take my old coins that I want to area coin dealers. Suggest you look up all coin dealers in the area and you can take them. Another place is a pawn shop, they will will not pay as much as a dealer. Last check with your area coin club, they hold meetings once a month and you can find them selling and buying coins and giving you fair market value.

First and foremost you need to establish the value of the coins you hold, there are numerous websites that will give you an indication of the value. Again there are a number of online sites you can list your coins on, coins fluctuate in value as it all depends on the demand. I have a number of coins, one of which is a Roman coin which is approximately two thousand years old and in excellent condition, which you would tend to think would have a high value, but they don’t as there are so many of them. So it pays to do your homework, GOOD LUCK.

I have sold gold and sliver coins in no time  I always prefer 5miles, easy to know the location of the seller or the buyer. Easy to ask questions about the product. Can share few more pic if needed.  Can arrange meeting in your location and best is transaction  of money. Hand to hand in no time. Been using 5miles from past 6months and sold around 9 items.   You have n number of apps now to sell and buy 2nd hand products. But in the end it depends on you how comfortable you are using one.  I found 5miles to be easy and fast.  Hope you too.

Depends on where you live.  If you are in highly rural areas like the great plains, best talk and find a collector to help you liquidate.  What ever you do, do not take them to a pawn shop.  They won't pay you anything for numismatic value.

Well what kind of coin is it? Is it gold or silver? A picture would help. And also when do you need to get the money for it, now or can you stand to wait a couple weeks? If you can wait a few weeks I know companies like APMEX and JM Bullion will let you mail them coins and they will examine them and then pay you. Depending on your coin it may be better just to walk into a coin shop. Describe the coin and send a pic.

To make it simple and short. Go to a local coin store, ask how to contact a Certified Grader or a Certification Company. Find out whether they are worth getting certified. Any of these can give you help on selling your coins. Oh, always go to two local stores so you have a second opinion. Good Luck.

Research it online and if it has numismatic or PM value you could take it to your nearest coin shop or pawn shop. Some jewelers deal in coins if they are precious metals. You could also put it up for auction on E-bay or take it to a coin show if there is one in your area. I would recommend AGAINST selling it on Craigslist or similar due to safety considerations.

Contact any numismatic auction house in India. Send the details of your coins to them and tell them you want to consign your coins for their next auction. Presently, a few auction houses are in the process of holding numismatic auctions at Kolkotta between December 20 and December 22, 2019.

depends on where you live.. the internet is possibly the best place from anywhere in the world.. research what you have and value them based on grade.. be honest with your grade, not all of your coins are the highest grade..

ebay or Facebook can be used for this purpose. there are various pages an groups on Facebook where you can upload details of your collection and sell it there. you can also get expert advice from there.
